Fig. 1 SEM images of (a) bare Fe2O3 and (b) Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes; the insets are cross-sectional view of the films. (c, d) Corresponding XRD patterns and Raman spectra, respectively. Fig. 2 High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Fe2p, (b) O1s, (c) B1s, and (d) Na1s in Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes. Fig. 3 (a) Low- and (b) high-resolution TEM images of bare Fe2O3 photoanode; (c) low-resolution TEM elemental mapping and (d) high-resolution TEM images of Fe2O3/FeB photoanode. Fig. 4 (a) Current density–voltage curves and (b) IPCE spectra measured at 1.23V vs. RHE for bare Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes. Fig. 5 (a) Charge separation efficiency and (b) injection efficiency at 1.23V vs. RHE for the Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes. Fig. 6 (a) Nyquist plots of Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes under AM 1.5G illumination, where the symbol and solid line represent experimental data and fitting results with (b) the equivalent circuit model for data fitting, as well as the fitting results. Fig. 7 Current density versus time measured at the potential of 1.23V vs. RHE and AM 1.5G illumination for a typical Fe2O3/FeB photoanode. Fig. 8 (a) Current density–voltage curves of the Fe2O3/Co–Pi and Fe2O3/FeB/Co–Pi photoanodes. Fig. 9 A mechanism for the increase of photocurrent density and negative shift of onset potential for Fe2O3 photoanodes after loading FeB and co-loading FeB and Co–Pi. Facile room-temperature surface modification of unprecedented FeB co-catalysts on Fe2O3 nanorod photoanodes for high photoelectrochemical performance Aizhen Liao a b Huichao He c Zhongwen Fan a b Guangzhou Xu a b Liang Li a b Jiani Chen d Qiutong Han a b Xingyu Chen a b Yong Zhou a b e ⁎ Zhigang Zou a b a Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Nano Technology, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, PR China Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Nano Technology Nanjing University Nanjing 210093 PR China b National Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures, Collaborative Innovation Center of Advanced Microstructures, Department of Physics, Eco-materials and Renewable Energy Research Center (ERERC), Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, PR China National Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures Collaborative Innovation Center of Advanced Microstructures Department of Physics Eco-materials and Renewable Energy Research Center (ERERC) Nanjing University Nanjing 210093 PR China c State Key Laboratory Cultivation Base for Nonmetal Composites and Functional Materials of Sichuan Province, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Southwest University of Science and Technology, Mianyang 621010, PR China State Key Laboratory Cultivation Base for Nonmetal Composites and Functional Materials of Sichuan Province School of Materials Science and Engineering Southwest University of Science and Technology Mianyang 621010 PR China d State Key Laboratory for Mineral Deposits Research, School of Earth Sciences and Engineering, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210046, PR China State Key Laboratory for Mineral Deposits Research School of Earth Sciences and Engineering Nanjing University Nanjing 210046 PR China e Key Laboratory of Modern Acoustics, MOE, Institute of Acoustics, Department of Physics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, PR China Key Laboratory of Modern Acoustics MOE Institute of Acoustics Department of Physics Nanjing University Nanjing 210093 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract An unprecedented FeB-based co-catalyst for Fe2O3 nanorod photoanodes is explored for the first time by a simple room-temperature dipping method. The FeB overlayer formed in situ, which inherently possesses good interfacial contact, can remarkably suppress charge carrier recombination in Fe2O3 photoanodes and dramatically decrease electrode/electrolyte interface resistance. These beneficial features promote a twofold increment in photocurrent density and significantly reduce the onset potential of Fe2O3 photoanodes. Furthermore, their photoelectrochemical (PEC) performance can be further improved by co-loading of Co–Pi. The photocurrent density of 1.9mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE and the particularly low onset potential of 0.61V, which is dominantly smaller than those reported so far, can be realized controllably. Hence, our work suggests a new and promising co-catalyst for Fe2O3 photoanode. It also offers a facile strategy for fabricating low-cost and efficient PEC solar energy conversion devices. Keywords Fe2O3 photoanode FeB overlayer Co-catalyst Carrier recombination Water splitting 1 Introduction Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting technology is an effective approach to renewable hydrogen production [1–3]. To realize efficient PEC water splitting, numerous promising materials that function as photoanodes in PEC devices have been explored, such as Fe2O3 [4,5], WO3 [6,7], BiVO4 [3,8,9], and Ta3N5 [10,11]. Among them, Fe2O3 is regarded as a high-potential one due to its earth abundance, nontoxicity, and superb PEC stability. Particularly, the ideal energy band gap (E g =2.1eV) allows the utilization of approximately 40% of the solar spectrum [12,13], which is nearly optimal for tandem cells in combination with lower bandgap semiconductors such as Si [14]. However, the experimental maximum solar conversion efficiency of Fe2O3 photoanodes is still far from the theoretical value (∼15.8%) due to several intrinsic limiting factors, such as sluggish oxygen evolution reaction kinetics, poor hole mobility, and short lifetime of carriers, which gives rise to serious carrier recombination [5,15–17]. To achieve high solar conversion efficiency, charge recombination within the bulk of the semiconductor and the electrode/electrolyte interface must be suppressed. Some strategies have been explored successfully to address the issue of carrier recombination in Fe2O3 photoanodes, such as element doping (e.g. Mg2+, Zn2+, Si4+, Ti4+, V5+, and Nb5+) [8–20], development of nanostructures (e.g., nanoribbons, nanobelts, nanorods, and mesoporous layers) [21–24], and incorporation of conducting scaffolds (e.g., graphene, carbon nanotubes, and ITO) [25–28], as well as surface modifications, which mainly include surface chemical corrosion, formation of heterojunctions, coating of passivation layers, and deposition of oxygen-evolution co-catalysts (OECs) [12,13,17,29,30]. Employment of OEC is proposed as a general method that can modify the electrode/electrolyte interface to promote water oxidation. This route is applicable not only to Fe2O3 but also to other photoanode materials. While cobalt- and nickel-based (e.g., CoO x , Co–Pi, MOOH [M=Fe, Ni, Co]) OECs have currently been demonstrated to be effective for enhancing the PEC performance of hematite [31–34], highly efficient and photostable OECs are still needed for continuous exploration. Metal borides, specifically iron borides (FeB), possess wide applications—for example, as surface coating materials and magnetic materials. FeB was introduced as an anode for a metal–air battery [35], whose exceptional electrochemical activity is owed to the alleviation of the passivation of the transition metal by clamping the potential to the negative region. In this work, we develop an unprecedented FeB-based OEC-on-Fe2O3-nanorod photoanode by simply dipping it into NaBH4 solution for tens of minutes at room temperature. The FeB overlayer formed in situ, which inherently possesses good interfacial contact, can remarkably suppress charge carrier recombination and dramatically decrease the electrode/electrolyte interface resistance of Fe2O3 photoanodes. Those desirable features enable faster hole transport from the photoanode surface to the electrolyte, and efficient hole migration across the electrode/electrolyte interface for the water oxidation reaction. Thus, the FeB-modified photoanode shows a twofold increment in photocurrent density and a significantly reduced onset potential (defined as the potential at which anodic current is first experimentally measured), in contrast to the bare photoanode It also exhibits excellent photostability, longer than 5h. The PEC performance of FeB-modified Fe2O3 photoanodes can be further improved by co-loading of Co–Pi, realizing a photocurrent density of 1.9mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE and a particularly low onset potential of 0.6V, much less than those reported so far. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation To prepare Fe2O3 nanorod photoanodes, an FeOOH layer was first grown on a fluorine-doped SnO2 (FTO) glass substrate by a hydrothermal process, and then it was annealed at 550°C for 2h and 650°C for 15min in air to convert to Fe2O3. For the hydrothermal process, a precleaned FTO glass slide (20×10×2mm) with sheet resistance 7Ω/sq was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave filled with 20mL aqueous solution containing 0.15M ferric chloride (FeCl3.6H2O, ≥99.99%), 0.3M urea (CO(NH2)2, AR, 99%) and 20μL titanium trichloride (TiCl3, AR, 15.0–20.0% TiCl3 basis in 30% HCl). Then the autoclave was heated at 100°C for 6h. After cooling down naturally, the films were taken out and washed with deionized water. The FeB overlayer was formed through dipping the Fe2O3 photoanode in 0.1M NaBH4 aqueous solution at room temperature for 40min, and finally washed with deionized water repeatedly. Thus the Fe2O3/FeB sample was obtained. The Co–Pi co-catalyst was loaded onto the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode by photoassisted electrodeposition under AM 1.5G illumination, which was carried out in a three-electrode cell at a constant voltage of 0.9V vs. Ag/AgCl electrode. The cell was filled with a solution containing 0.5mM cobalt nitrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99.99%) and 0.1M potassium phosphate (KH2PO4, AR, 99%). The pH of the solution was adjusted to 7 with phosphoric acid (GR, ≥85wt.% in H2O). A Pt foil was used as the counter electrode, and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode, with the Fe2O3/FeB sample serving as the working electrode. 2.2 Characterization An FEI NOVA NanoSEM230 scanning electron microscope was employed to investigate the morphology of samples. The crystal structure of samples was identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Ultima III, Rigaku) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154nm). The Raman spectrum measurement was conducted with a laser Raman spectrophotometer (JY-HR800). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were taken on a JEM 200CX TEM apparatus. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument operating with an unmonochromatized Al Kα X-ray source, and the data were calibrated by the binding energy of the C1s line at 283.6eV. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopic (EIS) curves were measured by a PAR2273 workstation (Princeton Applied Research, USA) under a forward bias of 0.2V and AM 1.5G illumination. The frequency ranged from 0.1mHz to 100kHz. A Shimadzu UV-2550 spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere was used to investigate the absorption properties of samples. 2.3 Photoelectrochemical property measurements The photoelectrochemical (PEC) performance of the photoanodes was investigated in a three-electrode cell using an electrochemical analyzer (CHI-630D, Shanghai Chenhua) under AM 1.5G illumination (standard 100mW/cm2) cast by an Oriel 92251A-1000 sunlight simulator calibrated by the standard reference of a Newport silicon solar cell. The electrolyte was a 1M NaOH aqueous solution (pH 13.6). The Fe2O3 sample was used as a working electrode. A Pt foil and a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode were used as a counter and a reference electrode. The RHE potential was calculated following the formula V RHE = V Ag/AgCl +0.059pH+ E Ag/AgCl, where V RHE is the converted potential versus RHE, and E Ag/AgCl o =0.1976V at 25°C. The active area of the Fe2O3 sample was fixed to 0.28cm2 using a black mask. The photocurrent of the sample was measured from the back side (electrolyte–substrate interface). A cyclic voltammetry method was adopted with a scan rate of 10mV/s. 3 Results and discussion The SEM images show that bare Fe2O3 and FeB-modified Fe2O3 (abbreviated as Fe2O3/FeB) photoanodes possess similar morphology, with a thin film of vertical nanorods covering the FTO substrate (Fig. 1 ). They indicate that 40min NaBH4 treatment has no obvious effect on the morphology of the Fe2O3 nanorod array. A cross-section view reveals that the length of the nanorods is less than 500nm (inset of Fig. 1). XRD patterns show characteristic diffraction peaks of hematite (α-Fe2O3; JCPDS 87-1165) and F-doped tin oxide (FTO; JCPDS 77-0452) (Fig. 1c). No additional peak is observed after NaBH4 treatment, perhaps because of the small amount of FeB formed. Prolongation of the dipping time to 2h allows the appearance of the diffraction peak of FeB (JCPDS 75-1065) (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Information). Raman spectroscopy also confirms the crystal phase of Fe2O3, exhibiting six characteristic Raman peaks of Fe2O3 at wavenumbers between 200 and 800cm−1 (Fig. 1d). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) verifies a peak located at 190.1eV, consistent with the binding energy of FeB, demonstrating the formation of FeB (Fig. 2 c) [36,37]. The Fe2p XPS spectrum shows two major peaks at ∼710.2eV for Fe2p 3/2 and ∼723.3eV for Fe2p 1/2. The binding energies of both peaks match well with the characteristics of Fe3+ in Fe2O3 (Fig. 2a). A small peak of Fe3+ located at 718.5eV can also be observed. The peak shows a slight blue shift, which can be ascribed to the charge-transfer or shakeup processes associated with Fe3+. The O1s peak can be fitted into two main constituent peaks centered at 528.9 and 530.4eV (Fig. 2b), which correspond to O2− and OH−, respectively [38–40]. The adsorbed OH− species in the NaBH4-treated sample decreases significantly in comparison with that of the bare sample, suggesting possible decrease of surface states, which is beneficial for improving PEC performance. The result of the Na1s XPS spectrum hints that all samples are rinsed completely (Fig. 2d), indirectly confirming the formation of FeB after NaBH4 treatment of Fe2O3. The low-resolution TEM image reveals one-dimensional morphology and the smooth surface of bare Fe2O3 (Fig. 3 a). The high-resolution TEM image reveals the distance of lattice fringes to be ∼0.27nm, which is consistent with the interplanar spacing of the (100) planes of Fe2O3, indicating a longitudinal growth direction of Fe2O3 nanorods along [100] (Fig. 3b). Elemental mapping images reveal that the Fe2O3/FeB sample possesses a homogeneous spatial distribution of Fe, O, and B species among bundles of nanorods over a large area (Fig. 3c), which further confirms the successful formation of an FeB thin layer on Fe2O3 nanorods. The TEM image of a single Fe2O3/FeB nanorod shows that the entire surface of the Fe2O3 is covered with a thin layer. The lattice fringes of the thin layer are ∼0.20nm, matching well the (021) crystallographic plane of FeB (Fig. 3d). Fig. 4 a shows the photocurrent density–potential curves of bare Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes. It can be seen that the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode exhibits considerably enhanced photocurrent density compared with that of the bare one, with about a twofold increase from 0.74 to 1.65mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE. Meanwhile, it also shows a cathodically shifted onset potential by about 80mV from 0.98 to 0.90V. These results indicate that loading of an FeB thin overlayer can increase photocurrent density and reduce onset potential for Fe2O3 photoanodes. In addition, the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode displays significantly enhanced incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) compared with that of the bare photoanode over the entire spectrum measured (Fig. 4b). The IPCE peak is about 60% at a wavelength of 380nm and the IPCE-integrated photocurrent density is 1.63mA/cm2 (Fig. S2). This is agreement with the J–V measurements. While no obvious change is observed in light absorption capability for the sample after NaBH4 treatment (Fig. S3), the enhanced PEC performance of the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode is thus believed to result from the FeB overlayer promoting separation of charge carriers, and subsequent transfer property across electrode/electrolyte interface. To clarify the role of the FeB overlayer, reliable extraction of the photocurrent density in 0.1M NaSO3 as a hole scavenger containing electrolyte solution (Fig. S4) allows evaluating the charge separation and injection of bare Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes, as plotted in Fig. 5 . The bare photoanode exhibits inferior separation efficiency (about 15%) at 1.23V vs. RHE, illustrating the high surface and bulk recombination and sluggish surface reaction. In contrast, the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode shows much higher separation efficiency at a bias of 0.96–1.62V vs. RHE, which may be because of holes being trapped rapidly by the FeB overlayer (Fig. 5a). The charge injection efficiency of both electrodes (i.e., the fraction of consumed holes in the O2 evolution once they reach the interface) begins to rise with increasing bias potential (Fig. 5b). It reaches 74% for the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode at 1.23 vs. RHE, which is significantly higher than for the bare photoanode, with a value of 43%. It can thus be inferred that the enhanced photocurrent density of the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode mainly comes from the synergistic effect of effective charge separation and increased charge injection efficiency. EIS tests are performed at 1.23 vs. RHE under AM 1.5G illumination conditions in order to understand charge transfer in the bare Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/FeB photoanodes. Fig. 6 a shows Nyquist plots of all the samples, where solid lines and symbols represent experimental data and fitting results of these data to an equivalent 2-RC (resistance and capacitance) circuit model (Fig. 6b). Here, R S is series resistance, which includes FTO and/or Fe2O3 films’ interface resistance and contact resistance of the test system. R 1 represents the internal resistance to charge transfer across the bulk Fe2O3 and FeB film surface, and R 2 corresponds to the charge transfer process occurring at the electrode/electrolyte interface for the water oxidation reaction. It can be seen that R 1 increases to 136.7Ω/cm2 for the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode from 26.43Ω/cm2 for the bare photoanode (Fig. 6b). It is reasonable that this increase comes from the partly suppressed charge carrier transfer due to the existence of FeB. However, R 2 decreases remarkably from 88.79kΩ/cm2 for the bare photoanode to 18.32kΩ/cm2 for the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode. This means that hole transport from the Fe2O3/FeB surface to the electrolyte becomes much faster than on the bare photoanode, which is consistent with the increase of its charge injection efficiency shown in Fig. 5b. This indicates that FeB overlay allows more holes to be captured efficiently and facilitates migration of holes across the electrode/electrolyte interface for the water oxidation reaction. Photostability is a very important feature for photoanodes, so the photocurrent density versus time for Fe2O3/FeB photoanode was further tested. As shown in Fig. 7 , it exhibits no obvious decay for more than 5h in 1M aqueous NaOH under AM 1.5G illumination, revealing excellent photostability. This also indicates that the enhanced photocurrent density of FeB-coated Fe2O3 does not originate from photocorrosion of the electrode, and the high PEC activity is not at the expense of photostability [4]. It is worthy of note that the present strategy can easily be followed at room temperature and be used facilely for industrial large-scale production, as preliminarily attempted in Fig. S5. To further enhance the PEC performance of the Fe2O3/FeB photoanode, a Co–Pi co-catalyst is subsequently loaded on its surface, and is labeled as Fe2O3/FeB/Co–Pi. The bare Fe2O3 photoanode is also prepared, for comparison, and is labeled as Fe2O3/FeB. As shown in Fig. 8 , the Fe2O3/FeB/Co–Pi sample shows a significantly enhanced photocurrent density of 1.9mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE when compared with Fe2O3/Co-Pi. Furthermore, a particularly low onset potential of 0.61V can be obtained, which is much smaller than those observed with other co-catalysts applied on Fe2O3 photoanodes (Table S1). The synergetic effect of the FeB overlayer and Co–Pi co-catalyst may be responsible for the improvement of PEC performance, in which holes first accumulate on FeB and further transfer to Co–Pi for efficient water oxidation, as schematically illustrated in Fig. 9 . 4 Conclusions In summary, a facile room-temperature solution route is proposed to enable the formation of an FeB overlayer on an Fe2O3 photoanode. The FeB overlayer, as an efficient OEC, can remarkably suppress charge carrier recombination and dramatically decrease the electrode/electrolyte interface resistance, thus significantly boosting the photocurrent density, and simultaneously reducing the onset potential for Fe2O3 photoanodes. It also shows excellent photostability. More importantly, the desirable photocurrent density of 1.9mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE and the particularly low onset potential of 0.61V can be further realized after co-loading Co–Pi. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the 973 Programs (Nos. 2014CB239302 and 2013CB632404), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 21473091, 51272101, and 51202005), and the Applied Basic Research Programs of the Science and Technology Department of Sichuan Province (2017JY0146). coredata.dc:description: An unprecedented FeB-based co-catalyst for Fe2O3 nanorod photoanodes is explored for the first time by a simple room-temperature dipping method. The FeB overlayer formed in situ, which inherently possesses good interfacial contact, can remarkably suppress charge carrier recombination in Fe2O3 photoanodes and dramatically decrease electrode/electrolyte interface resistance. These beneficial features promote a twofold increment in photocurrent density and significantly reduce the onset potential of Fe2O3 photoanodes. Furthermore, their photoelectrochemical (PEC) performance can be further improved by co-loading of Co–Pi. The photocurrent density of 1.9mA/cm2 at 1.23V vs. RHE and the particularly low onset potential of 0.61V, which is dominantly smaller than those reported so far, can be realized controllably. Hence, our work suggests a new and promising co-catalyst for Fe2O3 photoanode. It also offers a facile strategy for fabricating low-cost and efficient PEC solar energy conversion devices.
coredata.dc:title: Facile room-temperature surface modification of unprecedented FeB co-catalysts on Fe2O3 nanorod photoanodes for high photoelectrochemical performance
